1.Title: Intro
1.Info: This is the Equestrian Portrait of Charles I, Equestrian meaning he’s on horseback. It’s by Anthony van Dyck, painted in 1637 or 38. It’s oil on canvas, and as you can tell, it’s HUGE.

Charles was a passionate patron of painters; he’d brought Van Dyck to England to be his official painter, and this is one of several paintings Van Dyck made of Charles on horseback. So this very regal, very elegant painting gives us a lot of clues about what kind of king Charles wanted to be seen as. He’s wearing armour, but he doesn’t look like he’s about to charge off to battle, does he? He is bare-headed, and his expression is sad, preoccupied, almost resigned, I think. He looks more like a philosopher than a king, which fits with the image Charles himself tried to create of a cultured, intellectual ruler. From his pearl earring to his long, cavalier hair and tragic expression, this is an image of a new kind of king: serious, cultured and conscious of a sacred duty.
1.InsetCaption: Infra-red scans show Titian's initial drafting and how he changed his plan.

1.Info: Most royal paintings are full of symbols of kingship; but one of the only clues that this is a King is the Latin sign on this tree, which reads CAROLUS I REX MAGNAE BRITANIAE - King Charles I of Great Britain. The thing is, that wasn’t technically true; Charles’ father King James I had been the first King of both Scotland and England, and Charles was determined to continue his father’s legacy and unite the two countries as Great Britain - but it wasn’t until seventy years later, decades after Charles was defeated in the English Civil War and executed, that Scotland and England were formally united. So, like most royal paintings, this one is perhaps a bit liberal with the truth. I think this is Charles as he saw himself, or maybe as he hoped to be seen - even more so when you remember that he was quite a small man, very conscious of his height, and seems to have preferred to be painted on huge great horses like this one.

1.Title: Intro
1.Info: This was painted just a few years before Charles lost the English Civil War, his crown, and ultimately his head. It’s held at the National Gallery.

Just look at this majestic portrait of Charles I, by Van Dyck. It’s made me think: we will never really know what Charles I really looked like, will we? We’ve only got paintings of him, and well, look at it. That’s not a horse. Looks nothing like a horse. Either Van Dyck can’t paint horses, or he has 100% accurately painted a horse wearing a fatsuit. Also, he clearly painted this very quickly before Charles got his helmet on, judging by the cheeky latecomer in the right corner portrait-bombing the whole thing.
1.InsetCaption: Infra-red scans show Titian's initial drafting and how he changed his plan.

1.Info: A massive horse, a suit of armour and a sword. What more do you need to go into battle? An army might be nice, I suppose. Now, look at the tree on the right. Graffiti was more civilised then. They put it in a frame like real art, Banksy. And it was in Latin...“Hic erat Kilroy.” It just sounds classier! Of course, when people look at this painting at the National Gallery, they say Charles looks majestic and regal, but when I go around the gallery dressed like that I’m a “security issue”. Yes, maybe I should have left the horse at home. It’s not like I wasn’t going to clean up.

2.Title: Self Portrait as St. Catherine of Alexandria
Intro
2.Info: This is Italian Baroque artist Artemisia Gentileschi’s self portrait as St. Catherine of Alexandria, painted between 1615 and 1617. It is oil on canvas.

When she was alive, Artemisia’s work was called ‘animalistic’ by some; she was criticised for her lack of delicacy and elegance, especially her female characters. And indeed, many of her paintings show the kinds of things you don’t see depicted by male artists of the period: women being forced into compromised or sexualised positions by men, but with their distress clear on their faces and bodies. Artemisia took many of these female characters from Biblical stories or the lives of saints; here she has taken the story of Saint Catherine, a teacher and religious leader who defeated all opponents with piety, yes, but also with reason and strength of argument. And remember, this is a self-portrait; so here Artemisia depicts herself as the scholarly saint: with a determined, intense expression on her face, and the sleeves of her dress rolled up ready to get to work.

Artemisia was without doubt one of the greatest painters of her era; although her name wasn’t much known outside of art history circles for hundreds of years, in the last few decades her work has gained new recognition. I think this is such a strong painting, and it creates a very strong impression despite the almost drabness of the colours. She’s used very theatrical lighting, and her face is clearly highlighted, emerging out of the deep darkness on the right-hand-side of the painting, as if her skin is luminous. The harshness of the wooden, spiked wheel contrasts with the gentle rouge of her cheeks and the softness of the fabrics, especially the headscarf which trails down into delicate strands in the bottom right corner.

Please be aware: this part of the guide contains references to sexual assault.
It’s always tempting to look for clues in an artist’s life when you’re studying their paintings. In this case, there may be a bit more biography in this painting than most, but Artemisia isn’t hiding it; I think she wants us to hear what she’s saying loud and clear. When she was seventeen, Artemisia was raped by a painter who worked for her father. Artemisia was a witness in a trial that went on for months,and she was tortured with thumbscrews as part of the trial. Now her attacker was found guilty, but his conviction was overturned at the intervention of the pope amongst other people. At seventeen, Artemisia was already a breathtakingly talented painter working in her father’s studio, and yet in order to get justice she was forced to have her hands, the tools of her trade, crushed to prove her truthfulness. And here, just a few years later, she’s painting herself as Saint Catherine, who in the legend was a teenage princess and a scholar who defied the Roman Empire through eloquence and argument. Her hand rests on a spiked wooden wheel, a torture device called a Breaking Wheel which miraculously broke at a touch from the saint. Artemisia is looking out at us from this painting from over four hundred years ago, and I think it’s clear from the confidence and conviction on her face, that what she’s saying is: ‘Here I am. You can do what you want, say what you want about me but I know what’s true, and I know what’s right.’

2.Title: Intro
2.Info: Saint Catherine of Alexandria was a teenage princess and scholar who kept winning arguments and converting people despite persecution by the Roman Empire. The painting hangs in the National Gallery.

You’re now looking at Artemisia Gentileschi’s Italian baroque masterpiece Self Portrait as Saint Catherine of Alexandria, and as far as an early example of cosplay goes, it’s not bad, I think. She’d have a huge Tik-Tok following if she was around now. Of course, there are much more serious subjects going on in this painting. There’s a darkness to it, a sadness, but also a fierce determination. She’s ultimately a hero. Just like all the other cosplay people, but y'know, real.
Of course in those days, to take a self-portrait, or “selfpy” as they were called, you had to have a really, really long brush.

3.Title: Malala Yousafzai
3.Tomb: 2018, Archival ink on gelatin silver print

3.Title: intro
3.Info: This is Shirin Neshat’s portrait of the activist and Nobel Peace Prize laureate Malala Yousafzai made in 2018, and it’s in archival ink on gelatine silver print on paper.

I think this is an incredible picture. I say picture because, when I show this to students, they usually think it’s a painting. But it’s actually a photograph. Now, I’m a photographer, and photography is all about shadows and highlights. I love the way that the artist, the female Iranian photographer Shirin Neshat, has framed Malala so that she’s emerging from the shadows. The starkness of the black-and white, and the way the shadow frames her head, with her face framed in turn by the dark, soft fabric of her hijab… I think it brings all the attention to her eyes, the intensity of her gaze, looking straight out at us in a challenging, confident, empowering gaze. This is a portrait from a female perspective, capturing a powerful, defiant young woman while she’s looking out at the world, looking out at us, and waiting to see what we’re going to do.

Lean in close, and you can see that the artist has covered Malala’s face with fine hand-written calligraphy, everywhere except her eyes and her mouth, which seems fitting for an activist who’s famous for seeing the truth and speaking out. The writing is a poem by the Pakistani poet Rahmat Shah Syel, written in 2011. The poem is called Malala II, and in it the poet is talking to the legendary folk hero Malala of Maiwand, who rallied her community to victory in a battle with the British in the second Anglo-Afghan war in  1880. The poet is talking to the folk hero about her younger namesake, the modern activist Malala.

What I really love about this painting is its scale. You walk into a room where this is hanging, and Malala just takes over. Her powerful gaze; the quality of the photograph, which looks like a painting because of its fine lines, its sharpness, its detail. It's clearly evident to me, in how the artist has chosen to portray her: for me this piece is as much about the artist as the sitter. It exudes this incredible strength, and I think Neshat sees herself in Malala: a reflection of her work that addresses individual freedoms or those under attack or oppressed by social ideologies.

3.Title: intro
3.Info: This is actually a photograph, not a painting, and the artist has handwritten calligraphy across it. It hangs in the National Portrait Gallery.

You know when you look at a painting and you think it’s a photograph? Well, this photograph of Malala Yousafzai by Shirin Neshat is so striking, that you’d swear it was a painting. Obviously, when anyone writes on my face, I’m furious about it. In fact, I’m getting sick of it. But that’s what I like most about this piece. The artist has hand written in calligraphy the poem Malala II, aptly named after two Malalas, the first one being Malala of Maiwand, the folk hero who battled the British in the Anglo-Afghan war of 1880, and the second, about Malala Yousafzai herself.

A photo is not cheating, by the way. You try getting Malala Yousafzai to sit for a painting when she’s permanently saving the world. We’re lucky it wasn’t just a picture of a text saying “Soz, busy, Sad face”. Of course there’s writing on her face. She has so much to remember, it was only a matter of time before she’d run out of space on the back of her hand.

4.Title: intro
4.Info: This is believed to be a portrait of the poet and playwright William Shakespeare, probably by the painter John Taylor around 1600 to 1610, and it’s oil on canvas.

In the collection of the National Portrait Gallery, this is NPG1. It was the very first painting in the collection and was given to the gallery at its founding back in 1856. Now, I’m an educator at the National Portrait Gallery, and I think one really important thing about the Gallery is that it’s National; it’s for all of us to look at; it’s owned by all of us. And so it’s not just about Kings and Queens and celebrities; the collection reflects all people. The very first picture, one of our most famous pictures is of an ordinary man, with no jewels or crowns or weapons or signs of statehood; a man from Stratford who made his living by the pen, and became one of the most celebrated writers of any era. I think it’s a great reminder that the most important, the most impactful people, the people we remember from a period of history, aren’t always the ones with the crown on their head or the big plaque on the wall.

This is the only portrait of Shakespeare that has a good claim to have been painted from life, which means that of the handful of portraits that supposedly depict him, this one has the most evidence to support that claim. We believe it was painted by a painter called John Taylor who was a contemporary of Shakespeare. Now, there are other pictures of Shakespeare, probably not done from life, which show him as majestic, as well dressed, like a royal courtier. There have been times in history when people thought that this picture couldn’t be the great poet, the Bard, because he looks a little, well… scruffy. Untidy. He’s let himself go a bit, and he looks like a bit of a ruffian, with his earring and his collar undone, and this very… ambiguous expression. But I think that’s the heart of it. Like Shakespeare’s plays, this painting doesn’t let us say “this is what this means” or “this is what he’s thinking”. I think this is Shakespeare, because to me, this is a picture of an artist, a man who moved between the very lowest levels, and the very highest levels of his society, and who in his plays, understood all of life in between.

4.Title: intro
4.Info: The painting is also called the Chandos Portrait because it was formerly owned by the Dukes of Chandos. It now hangs in the National Portrait Gallery.

You're looking at a portrait of William Shakespeare by the artist John Taylor... I think. The thing is, nobody knows exactly when this was painted (probably somewhere around 1600-1610), but nobody knows who painted it and nobody is completely sure who the painting is of. But the National Portrait Gallery researchers reckon it’s probably your man Shakespeare. What we do know for sure is that the painting you are looking at was the very first painting EVER in the National Portrait Gallery’s collection. Sounds impressive, so long as it wasn’t the only one for long. One picture in a room, that is not a gallery, it’s just a painting. A painting by someone they’re not sure about of someone who may or may not be Shakespeare. It would have been a proper farce. Which he’d have loved, by the way.

The problem with correctly identifying this painting is that everyone looked like William Shakespeare in those days. This could be Elizabeth I for all we know. Look at his face. He looks like he’s just missed a deadline and doesn’t care, in which case, he’s definitely a writer. If this isn’t William Shakespeare, then this guy must have been sick of people coming up to him all the time saying “Alright mate, what were you on when you wrote Midsummer Night’s Dream?”.or “As You Like It? Call that a play? As I Hate It more like!”.

5.Title: Tom Jones
5.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

5.Title: inotr
5.Info: This is Duncan Shoosmith’s portrait of the singer and Welsh icon Sir Tom Jones, and it’s oil on canvas. It was Duncan’s prize commission for winning Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the Year in 2019, and it was created for the National Museum of Wales.

This is Duncan Shoosmith painting Tom Jones for the National Museum of Wales - I would think that that was quite a lot of pressure! All these commissions are hung in very venerable institutions, but you are painting one of Wales's favourite sons, to go in their National Museum.

Duncan was a technically incredibly accomplished painter; he paints a lot of portraits, and you can tell he really knows how to do it and what works. What I found interesting was that he painted so many versions of this, so many Tom Joneses! I mean dozens of them. In order to get the one Tom Jones that he thought really captured the man. And I think this does capture Tom's charisma, his slight melancholy, his thoughtfulness, and also, what a handsome bloke he is!

Duncan really did come across some extraordinary sitters in the course of winning Portrait Artist of the Year 2019. Before this he painted Cleo Lane in an absolutely fantastic portrait with her looking down, with a huge head, capturing all her slightly intimidatory presence! And here he's got Tom Jones, who during one sitting started singing! Which I think, if you're a portrait painter, painting one of the world's greatest singers, and they start singing. I think that would count as a good day at work!

6.Title: Intro
6.Info: This is a portrait of the British-Jamaican nurse and healer Mary Seacole by Albert Charles Challen in 1869, and it’s oil on a wooden board.

6.Title: Intro
6.Info: Mary Seacole’s story of heroism is similar to Florence Nightingale, who also worked as a pioneering nurse in the Crimean War, but Mary was almost unknown to history until just a few years ago. Now this painting hangs in the National Portrait Gallery.

Mary Seacole led a truly incredible life, and I think the painter, Challen, has captured something really strong, majestic in his composition here, especially in the position of her head; she’s looking away from us, almost as though she’s looking into the past and remembering, maybe remembering her struggle to set up as a nurse for the British Army in the Crimean War in 1853, and then her struggle afterwards to be recognised for her work, a struggle that goes on today. And the story of this painting actually mirrors Mary’s story. We don’t know much about the painter, Albert Challen, who may have been a friend or neighbour of Mary’s in London, and this painting wasn’t even found until 2004, because it was being used as the backing for another painting; hidden away for more than a century behind a picture of someone else. Now at last this painting, and Mary’s achievements as a medical pioneer, are here for all to see.

I love the way that Mary has been painted. It’s quite a small painting, but that’s not important; what’s more important is how she’s represented. It’s such an empowering painting; her pose is quite heroic, she’s gazing away with authority, as if surveying her domain, and the layers of colour add a real boldness and importance. The highlights and shadows on her face create depth and texture that emphasizes her weathered skin and reminds us of her age, but also her adventurous life and her bravery as a war nurse. And then there’s this powerful red, alongside this very royal blue of her clothing… in many ways it’s a very regal painting, which feels right for Mary, the queen of the nursing brigade!

This painting was lost until 2004, and when it was found, one of the ways we were able to identify its subject was these medals. During her lifetime Mary was well known for proudly wearing her dress medals from the British and allied armies in the Crimean War to the many benefits that were held in her honour by soldiers that she had nursed during the war. Mary was extremely proud of her work during the war and her devotion as a healer, which went right back to her  childhood as part of a long tradition of Jamaican and West African Doctresses. Mary said in her biography that she had “from early youth a yearning for medical knowledge and practice which never deserted me…. And I was very young when I began to make use of the little knowledge I had acquired from watching my mother, upon ‘Great Sufferer’ – my doll… whatever disease was most prevalent in Kingston, be sure my poor doll soon contracted it.”

This is a painting of a hero. You can tell that without knowing much about her. She’s striking a very heroic pose, she’s wearing dress medals and this painting makes her look like one of The Avengers. She is Mary Seacole, painted in 1869 by Albert Charles Challen. Mary travelled the world as a nurse throughout her life, healing the sick and even setting up a hotel during the Crimean War to look after sick and injured British troops, and later in her life, the soldiers she’d healed would throw huge benefits in her honour. After enjoying this amazing piece, you might want to check your attic for treasures. This painting went unseen for over a hundred years until 2004 when it turned up in a car boot sale. I regret everything I have ever put in the bin.

Is she pretending to ignore the artist? I like the attitude of if you’ve got it, flaunt it. That’s why when Mary Seacole poses for a painting, she’s wearing her dress medals. When the Queen poses, she wears a crown and when I finally get painted, I’ll be wearing my five Edinburgh Comedy Award Nominee plaques. Yeah, I didn’t win, that is not the point. Mary Seacole was 65 when she posed for this painting in 1869, while Albert Charles Challen was just 22. That must have been awful. Her going on about the death of Napoleon and the Greek War of Independence like some old fuddy duddy, while he desperately wants to talk about things young people are into like War and Peace being published and the latest penny farthing upgrade. Albert, we’ve all been there mate.

7.Title: intro
7.Info: This artwork is called Design, by Angelica Kauffman and dates back to 1778.

7.Title: intro
7.Info: The painting is oil on canvas, and now decorates the ceiling of the entrance hall of the Royal Academy.

In the 1770s, when this was painted, women weren’t allowed to take part in life drawing classes, even at the Royal Academy. I guess in many ways, someone who’s not really an artist or a draw-er might find this bust unattractive  - that there’s no head, no arms, it’s arched in a certain way. But I think it’s a perfect sculpture for people who study or practice  life drawing. At the RA, there are a lot of casts that look like this, either destroyed or made in that way to model the human figure. In real life, models do have to make awkward and maybe embarrassing poses in order for us to learn about the realities of the human body.

The title of this work is ‘Design’, which almost feels like too simple a title for a painting where there’s so much going on. It’s one of four paintings by Kauffman, about the elements of art: Invention, Composition, Design and Colour, which was based on contemporary theories of art by Sir Joshua Reynolds. Looking at all the different half-done drafts at her feet, I feel like maybe the title of this painting could have been ‘Process’. It seems like she has done a few drawings, and is trying to perfect whatever she’s working on. We mainly focus on her pose, her stance, her glare. I think it’s very intense. Which is why the background of clouds gives it this very dreamy effect. There’s the intensity of process, and then there’s the dreamy, kind of blue-sky thinking all around it.

Angelica Kauffman was one of the two female founding members of the Royal Academy. She was actually born in Switzerland, and the world she was born into was not one in which women had easy access to artistic training and schools. But she was an incredibly talented artist who was recognised as a prodigious talent even as a young child.  She came to England and worked alongside Sir Joshua Reynolds, the first president of the Royal Academy and one of the most famous painters of the day. It’s a painting about the process of making art, using a female artist as its subject, painted at a time when female artists were underrepresented and underestimated. So it’s a powerful statement, especially as the four paintings the“Elements of Art”  were commissioned to decorate the council room of the first Royal Academy building at Somerset House. The work still hangs in the entrance hall of the Royal Academy building at Burlington House, so there’s no doubt that Kauffman has influenced generations of artists after her.

This painting, ‘Design’, is one of four by Kauffman depicting the four fundamental “Elements of Art” as described by Sir Joshua Reynolds: Invention, Composition, Design, and Colour. So this painting is showing one of an artist’s most fundamental skills: the first moment of making marks on a blank paper or canvas, with the artist practising their skill copying a plaster cast of a famous sculpture, like all students at the Academy. As a woman, Kaufmann was not permitted to move to the next stage: studying real nude male human forms. But nonetheless, even though this is a painting of anartist practising a core skill, it’s also full of classical references and other touches that show Kaufmann placing herself alongside the other great artists of her day - the subject of the painting has a classical greco-roman profile, and stylisedhairand pose, while the columns in the background invoke the great architects of Antiquity or the Renaissance. The artist iss showing her technical skill, but also her more elevated, poetic vision; which is what Reynolds thought artists should aspire to.

8.Title: Ian McKellen
8.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

8.Title: Intro
8.Info: This is Christian Hook’s portrait of the actor and champion of gay rights Sir Ian McKellan, and it’s oil on canvas. It was Christian’s winning painting as Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the Year in 2014.

8.Title: ik1
8.Info: This is Christian Hook, painting Sir Ian McKellen. And what I love about this painting is his choice of colours; they're almost like sweets. You feel like you could almost eat them. There's something really delicious about the colours that he's used. Also a sense of movement. We've got a very pensive, slightly sad Ian McKellen, but there's also a great feeling of movement. Christian also painted Amir Khan, and Alan Cumming, and in all those portraits he manages to get the sense that there is movement happening.

8.Title: ik2
8.Info: I know that Christian relies on what he calls happy accidents; things that just happen by chance as the paint hits the canvas. And of course, all of us can have happy accidents, but his talent is to know which, and to spot them in the first place, and to know how to incorporate them with great skill. Christian Hook is a really technically extraordinary painter who gives the impression he can do anything. It's sickening, frankly.

9.Title: intro
9.Info: This is a portrait of Sir Noel Coward by his friend the painter and writer Clemence Dane, from before 1939, and it’s oil on canvas.

9.Title: intro
9.Info: The portrait is in the collection of the National Portrait Gallery, one of over a hundred items in the collection associated with Coward.

For me, what I find most interesting about this painting is that Coward was famous for his flamboyance, his wit, his sparkling presence. And yet, this painting is quite meditative. He’s concentrating; his focus is somewhere else entirely. I think it shows a really strong relationship with the painter, Clemence Dane, who was an artistic prodigy in her own right and who won an Oscar for writing the film Perfect Strangers. There was obviously a lot of trust between the painter and the sitter, between these two artists, because here Clemence has captured the famous showman in a moment of introspection; there’s nothing of that flamboyance, and it’s unposed, dreamy, kind of vulnerable even.

One thing we know about this painting is that the artist, Coward’s friend Clemence Dane, was actually teaching Coward himself to paint when she painted this. We know that Coward was considered an artistic polymath; he was a playwright, an actor, a lyricist and composer, and clearly he was trying to broaden his artistic horizons still further. So it’s a painting about painting, about the creative process perhaps. The colour and pattern of the background could almost give us a sense of what’s going on inside his head, and yet it’s almost as though he’s disappearing into the background too, as though he’s become utterly lost in the creative process.

You’re looking at the world-renowned effervescent wit and flamboyant performer Noel Coward, and like all comedians, this is the exact face we make when someone comes up to us after a show to tell us a joke. The only painting at the National Portrait Gallery to be painted by an Oscar winner, namely Clemence Dane in 1939, it shows Noel in a much more serious and pensive mood than we might be used to seeing him in. If you look closely, it even looks like he’s blowing cigarette smoke out of his mouth. And if you’re thinking, well, he doesn’t look funny. You’re wrong. One of the quickest wits ever known, and that bow-tie? It spins round. Classic.

So, this is what it looks like when you’ve been sitting for hours waiting for your portrait artist to turn up, only to realise she snuck in and captured your likeness while you were busy thinking about something else. Clemence Dane actually painted this while she was giving Noel Coward a painting lesson. By the looks of things, Noel was crap.

10.Title: intro
10.Info: This is Georges Seurat’s painting Bathers at Asnières. This painting is oil on canvas, and it was finished in 1884.

Just look at the boy in the hat. Seurat is well known for his development of the technique known as pointillism, which is where tiny individual dots of different colours are used together to create an overall colour effect. As with a lot of art movements, its name, ‘pointillism’, was originally used by critics to make fun of it! But, although in 1884 Seurat was already studying the new sciences of colour and optics which would inspire the technique, this isn’t a pointillist painting, although he is experimenting  with a new brushstroke, criss-cross technique called Balaye - and you can see this in the grass in the foreground of the painting . But the boy in the hat stands out, doesn’t he? He’s almost haloed in a different kind of light. And if you look closely you can see the orange hat was reworked with dots of red and blue, building up an impression of colour. Right there, that is the beginning of pointillism.

Oddly enough, I think this is actually quite a “2020” painting! Everyone depicted is very socially distanced, very solitary. They’re even practicing the rule of six! And yet, I think this is a very calming, still painting - the way the subjects have been painted is almost statue-esque; they have all been very carefully arranged in fixed positions, and they seem to be almost sculpted into smooth surfaces like alabaster.He’s depicted people together, and yet they’re carefully arranged to be separate, each isolated and lost in their own thoughts; I think this painting has a lot to say about our own world right now.

As you can see, this is a truly massive painting! In Seurat’s time, paintings of this size were usually associated with grand, historical or mythological paintings - not chill riverbank scenes of ordinary Parisians sitting on the grass. Seurat is elevating the everyday here, showing ordinary people lost in their thoughts, but on a grand scale. At the same time, this very ordinariness caused some to criticise the painting. Seurat submitted it to the 1884 Salon of the Académie des Beaux-Arts, the biggest art exhibition in Europe, but it was rejected partly because it lacked epic grandeur. So Seurat banded together with some like-minded artists and staged their own exhibition of independents - but even then, this painting was hung in the exhibition’s beer hall! It wasn’t until decades later that this painting was widely seen as a masterpiece, and now it’s one of the highlights of the National Gallery collection.

10.Title: intro
10.Info: It’s hanging in the National Gallery.

There are so few paintings like the beautiful “Bathers at Asnieres”, by Georges Seurat that really make me feel like buying a hat. In 1888, hats were very much the smart phone of their day. Everyone had one. George was only 24 when he painted this masterpiece depicting an idyllic Parisian summer’s day over 130 years ago, and it’s pretty astonishing how contemporary it looks now. Everyone’s socially distant, there’s a factory in the background polluting the air and, if you look carefully in the left hand corner, you’ll see a laptop. Oh, no. It’s a dog.

Look at the man and the dog on the left. I hate it when couples come out and they’re clearly not speaking. A beautiful, idyllic summer’s day. It’s just nice to see people enjoying themselves and not just looking at Instagram, to be honest. Mind you, back then you couldn’t move without some artist poling up and immortalising you. That kid in the water calling out “Help! Help me! I’m being painted again!”

11.Title: intro
11.Info: This 1978 painting by Eileen Agar is acrylic on canvas.

11.Title: intro
11.Info: The painting is in the collection of the Royal Academy.

I really like Agar, I only discovered her work maybe a year ago but I really love everything about her being. I find her quite funny in her self portraits! With this painting, I love how bold she’s being here, I love the use of colour. She’s well known for her use of collage, combining different elements in her earlier work - shells, fossils and seaweed. And here in this painting, there’s just so many elements and layers. It looks like a print. I wouldn't be surprised if a fashion house tried to interpret her work, and tried to put it on trousers or on a dress.

It’s kind of a confusing painting, but in a good way. Because Eileen Agar came from the surrealist school, it makes sense that this was the type of work she was interested in. There’s always visual puns in surrealist work, things that don’t make sense, there’s always unexpected weird meanings unless the artist says, “This is what I’m trying to say”. Because Agar was quite a unique, unpredictable individual, there’s not much realism in this work compared to others. Maybe it’s not meant to make sense: whatever she's trying to perceive or depict, maybe you get it or maybe you don't. But I wouldn't think she'd want to explain what's going on.

I think this is such a bold piece of work. Remember the title: Collective Unconscious. It’s very relevant I think. At this moment in time, in 2020, everyone is a bit confused. There’s a pandemic, and no-one knows what’s going to happen next. At the period in the 70s when this was painted, there was also a lot going on in the collective unconscious. In life, things are unpredictable, things are spontaneous and happen by chance. Even when things are organised, they’re in amongst other chaotic elements. And I think in this work Agar is reflecting all of that. Agar herself said that in order to be an artist, one must have “new possibilities of discovery.” Maybe this painting is about that journey of discovery. I think no matter when it’s presented, especially with this title, this painting will always be relevant and timeless.

What do you think this painting is depicting? And, what do you think the artist who painted it wanted you to feel? I don’t think there are definitive answers to these questions; in fact I think maybe this painting is about us asking those questions. If we learn that thehe artist, Eileen Agar, was fascinated by sea shells and molluscs, fossils, bones and shells, and spent a lot of time in Paris at the Jardin des Plantes looking at these kinds of objects,it might be that you can see some of these kinds of shapes in this painting… but others might be content to be drawn into the shapes and colours of the painting, and feel rather than understand. I think by the time Agar was painting  artists were more and more aware of the different ways a viewer might engage with a painting, and also we as viewers bring more and more of ourselves to every work we look at. This painting seems to resist meaning; it can become an exploration of  you bring to it. I’m not sure myself what she's thinking but I'm also not sure that matters.

Eileen Agar was very interested in collage, in abstraction. She was fascinated by shapes and as you can see, she was a dazzling colourist. She was often thought of as part of the Surrealist movement, but actually she didn’t identify with that label herself. In some ways this painting might reminds us of a classic abstract painter. But, are these real objects presented to us differently to enable us to better understand them or are they moving us away from the real thing, with shapes and colours that seem like their meaning is something beyond bodily reality.

12.Title: We Move in Her Way: Dancers
intro
12.Info: This 2017 work by Sonia Boyce is an edited photograph from an improvised immersive performance directed by the artist.

12.Title: intro
12.Info: It’s currently in the collection of the Royal Academy.

We could talk for hours about this work: what the artist is doing, and what we can take from it. It reminds me of a kaleidoscope. In many ways it’s all about capturing movement, and arranging it into these visual cycles, full of repetition. The artist, Sonia Boyce, stages improvised, immersive performances to capture this kind of photograph. And I think there’s a playful element - I wouldn't say funny, but definitely an element of play.

There’s always some element of power in any artwork, and I think there’s a lot about power and position in this photograph. To me, in a way, it’s depicting the position of women,  and the certain way or stance we have to navigate the world. The woman performer here is the centre of attention, and she’s got this kind of kung-fu stance that is historically not associated with women. If a guy did that pose we might say he's powerful, strong, disciplined. If a woman does this, what is she trying to do? Impersonate a man? Especially with her shaved head, I think there are definitely questions of gender at play. And when you’re a woman or a person of colour, with a strong stance or manner of being, then you sometimes get accused of being disruptive or angry. It’s important to squash those stereotypes. Sonia Boyce is a strong artist with a very definitive vision. And she's making history by being the first black woman to represent the UK at the Venice Biennale.

Make sure you get up close to this work! It may look like a very abstract work, but when you get in close you can see that these aren’t abstract shapes; it’s a photographic still of a whole other work of art. It’s a still from a film - a film of a live immersive performance directed by the artist Sonia Boyce. And the image of a female performer is repeated and multiplied within the painting, with the body and limbs of another performer visible behind her. The central performer is reflected, almost confronting herself, and yet the way the photo has been arranged, with the performer’s hand meeting her reflection’s hand, almost like a connection between them. It isn’t a connection between a real person and their reflection - somehow they are all reflections, carefully arranged. Even though we’re outside this photograph, looking in, I think the artist wants us to draw us in, to feel like we’re part of the image and the movement, not just a viewer.

As you’re looking at this work, keep in mind the title: We Move in Her Way. I think the artist wants to invite us in, and wants us to think about how we participate with a work as we look at it. There’s so much movementyet it’s made up of static images; like in an animation, our brains help create a sense of motion from one image to the next. Because the images are repeated and reflected, it creates a looping, kaleidoscope-like effect; even though this is a still image from a live performance, I think it’s still exploring how bodies move through space - and through time.

13.Title: Diana and Actaeon
13.Info: Diana and Actaeon is a painting by the Italian Renaissance master Titian, finished in 1556–1559, and is considered amongst Titian's greatest works. It portrays the moment in which the hunter Actaeon bursts in where the goddess Diana and her nymphs are bathing.

13.Title: intro
13.Info: This is Diana and Actaeon by the Italian Renaissance artist Titian. It was finished between 1556 and 1559 as part of a commission for Prince Phillip II of Spain, and it’s oil on canvas.

This painting shows the moment that determines the end of Acateon’s life. Actaeon is the male hunter at the left of the painting and, in the original ancient myth, he accidentally stumbles upon the goddess Diana, who’s seated on the right, when she’s bathing in a spring in a forest. Outraged to be seen naked, Diana curses him and transforms him into a stag, and he is hunted down and killed by his own hounds. Titian is showing us a frozen moment just as Actaeon pulls back that red cloth; from that instant, his fate is sealed. And although Actaeon is the one who is clothed, he is the one who looks the most vulnerable, doesn’t he? The women’s nudity doesn’t make them the victims here, because they are the ones who are doing all the looking; in some ways they have the power.

Art historians have typically considered the five nude white women in the centre of the painting to be nymphs, that is, mythical companions of the goddess, and labeled the Black woman at the far right a servant or attendant. However, the painting is based on a poem by Ovid, who names six nymphs in the poem, and there are six women in the painting other than Diana - when you include the Black woman. In fact, Ovid describes one of the nymphs, Crocale, which means ‘beach’ or ‘seashore’, as being particularly good at doing Diana’s hair. The Black woman’s position and close attendance to Diana’s head has recently led some scholars to identify her as potentially Crocale. Venice, where Titian lived, was a particualrly multicultural place in the 16th Century and home to numerous people of colour, so Titian would certainly have encountered Black people in normal life. In fact, art historians generally agree that unlike the white nymphs, who all have the same almost generic face, the Black woman’s face is so distinctive that it must have been painted from life.

Titian was by far the most famous painter in Europe by the time this painting, one of six, was commissioned by Phillip II, who was probably the most powerful man in Europe, and a young man in his twenties besides. The six-painting commission was unusually flexible: as Titian had free reign over the subject matter and composition. And after he'd completed the first painting, he writes to Phillip, and tells him that in this one, the front part of the naked body is visible; but in the next painting he sends, will be showing the opposite side of the body. Here in this painting, in the centre, we see the naked nymphs from a range of angles, but also see a range of reactions on their faces, from shock and shyness to almost titillation - and yet, they are all waiting to see what their mistress Diana will do. And what she’s going to do is curse Actaeon to a very violent death. Titian is certainly presenting a range of female nakedness, but also asking difficult questions: while you are looking at all this nudity, who is looking back? And who is really in control?

13.Title: intro
13.Info: The painting shows a story from Greek myth: the hunter Actaeon, on the left, has accidentally walked in on the goddess Diana, on the right, while she’s in the bath. Right after this, she transforms him into a stag as punishment. The painting hangs in the National Gallery.

You’re looking at the painting “Diana and Acteon” by Titian, from around 1556, and it tells the story of a situation we’ve all been in before. The story of an idiot who forgot to knock on the curtain before entering a ladies changing room. The idiot in question is Acteon, the hunter on the left hand side of the painting, and he’s walked in on Diana, the Goddess of the Hunt, while she’s having a bath (admittedly with 6 other people, or, ‘nymphs’ as they were known back then), and in a move I can only be impressed with, she does what any of us would do in this situation: splashes him with water, curses him, and turns him into a stag. Good for her! This painting shows the moment just as Actaeon barges in, and Titian’s captured what must surely be one of the most exquisitely awkward moments in all of art. If you’re feeling a bit awkward looking at this painting, there’s a little dog in the right hand corner. Just look at the dog. Keep your eyes on the dog.

I'll be honest, until someone told me what this painting was about, I thought it was a bunch of young people just hanging out by a fountain and getting told to clear off by the local fuzz. None of it makes any sense to me - certainly, if someone said to me, "what happens next?" my last guess qould have been, "that guy gets turned into a stag." I actually thought he was the goody! Goes to show, context is everything.

14.Title: intro
14.Info: This painting is called Spring by Mary Moser, one of only two founding female members of the Royal Academy.

14.Title: intro
14.Info: The painting is from 1780, it’s oil on canvas, and it’s currently in the collection of the Royal Academy.

Mary Moser was the youngest founding member of the RA at 24 years old and one of only two founding women. She came from quite a privileged background since her father was George Michael Moser, who was a very well-known artist, and the first keeper of the RA schools. The Royal Academy were pioneers in many ways but it was still extremely unusual and difficult for women artists to be accepted at all.

I love that this piece of work is very pretty and romantic, but it still has a realism to it. We can clearly identify lots of different flowers - tulips, lilies and daffodils. And although the background is quite dark I think there is a romantic element to it. The darkness behind the flowers brings the colours to the front, but also gives it this kind of melodramatic vibe. When I look at this painting I think of contemporary still life photography, like the work of Irving Penn, who brought an aesthetic eye from fashion photography into still life. I think it’s the composition of this painting, and how detailed it is - like in photography you get every element.

I’m a big fan of this particular painting! Mary Moser was a painter of portraits and historical paintings like many of the other great artists of her period, but she became probably best known for her flower paintings like this. And in fact, it was because of this type of work that Moser was made the teacher to the royal princesses, the daughters of George III and Queen Charlotte. This started a bit of a fashion for floral paintings, in fact one whole room of the Queen’s house at Frogmore was entirely decorated with Moser’s floral work - it’s still called the Mary Moser Room.

This painting continues a strong tradition of flower painting which began the 1600s, particularly in the Dutch tradition. But by the time Moser was painting it was also  a period of scientific enlightenment and close study of nature. If a flower painter couldn’t have access to a real flower because it wasn’t in season, they might compile an image from botanical drawings and manuals. This meant that artists could present arrangements of flowers that could never actually happen in real life, because one or other of the blooms would have wilted. To an audience in the 1700s, this could have been a reminder of the passage of time, and the impermanence of all ‘worldly’ things. Moser was a highly educated artist, and she would certainly have known that she was engaging in the Dutch tradition of vanitas - where paintings remind us of the emptiness of putting too much value on fleeting beauty, when life is short.

15.Title: intro
15.Info: This is ‘Trying to Find You One’ by the artist Tracey Emin.

15.Title: intro
15.Info: It’s a small painting in acrylic on canvas, and it’s in the collection of the Royal Academy.

Tracey Emin is someone that I really admire. I think she’s a bold, badass artist who doesn't suffer no fools. People sometimes say that this is a loose self portrait, but I'm not really sure. We’re all human; we have our ups and downs, but somehow I can never imagine Emin doing this pose in real life. When I first saw this work I thought there's definitely some religious connotations. If you go back to the title, "Trying to Find You 1", it has an emotive feel. Who are we trying to find? God? A partner? There’s lots of meanings behind it, but there’s definitely some elements of romanticism, and eroticism. And Emin does get criticised for her drawings being unrealistic, but I like how messy it is. I don't think romance or religion are neat or tidy or ordered.

This female body is just an outline: you can see the background colours through the body. Emin’s self-portraits will often just be outlines like this, without blocks of colour - she doesn’t fill them in. I guess that's why some people say there's weakness or vulnerability in this painting, because there's not much detail. But I think being an outline doesn't make it either weak or vulnerable. I think it makes it strong and minimalist. You get what you see. You don’t need the details of hair, toenails and so on; the outline is powerful and strong. I think being vulnerable is a powerful move which shouldn't be seen as a sign of weakness. Emin puts herself out there, and there's a power in nakedness, in baring your flaws and insecurities.

What we know of an artist’s life often leads us to interpret their work in one way or another, and when we talk about art we need to make sure not to confuse the artist and the artwork. But, I think there is something so… autobiographical about this painting. It’s called ‘Trying to Find You One’, and I think combined with the colours, the rawness, it creates this sense of searching, questing, almost desperation in seeking something. Emin has always been very honest about her own quests and searching and sexuality and relationships, and her work often lays that open in a way that isn’t at all glamorizing. Even those red lines that make up the woman’s body in the painting - when I look at what she does, it makes me think of the blood that runs in her veins, and the blood that women bleed. The quite visceral gritty qualities of it that come out of suffering and questing and that's something Emin is open about and talks about a lot, and it’s one of the things that make her such an exciting artist.

I think whenever a modern artist shows a female nude , inevitably, they’re engaging with a long tradition in Western art , running from Venus in antiquity through centuries of representations of women. These are so often about the ideal, beautified female body presented for the male gaze and male consumption. One of the things I like about Tracey Emin is that this is still a work that could be available to a consumer in that way, that could have that eroticised element, but it doesn’t perform for the delight of the viewer. It’s doing something else. The sense of intimacy, the woman’s pose of supplication or despair, the way her breasts hang down - it’s not trying to be erotic, and it’s not trying to be for us - I think this is a very personal story, that the artist is sharing with us, perhaps to make us think about our own stories.

16.Title: intro
16.Info: This is a portrait of the celebrated opera singer Sir Willard White by Ishbel Myserscough in 2009, and it’s oil on canvas

16.Title: intro2
16.Info: The painting is part of the collection of the National Portrait Gallery.

This is such a strong picture. That powerful, steady gaze that the subject has, his sure, confident stance, and the colours that the artist has used are minimal but so bold. The black perfectly outlines his fabulous chest, and that’s such a part of what makes an opera singer. And then, the colour of the background, this theatrical pink, maybe a reminder of his work on the stage, but the colour also makes him stand out; it pushes him outwards closer to us. Even though he’s still, at peace, it’s as though he’s also ready to swell outward and out of the painting and burst into song any second!

The artist behind this portrait, Ishbel Myerscough, says being a portrait artist is a bit like being a hairdresser: she said that like a hairdresser, “painting a portrait permits one to have an unusual intimacy with one’s subject.” Myerscough staged several sittings at the subject’s own home in South London, and she said that although the beloved baritone didn’t sing in front of her, she could always hear him singing as he moved around the house. I think it’s clear she got to know him quite well from this painting. Even though he’s quite posed, and we can see that this is a performance, where he’s kind of holding us at arms length… we’re also brought in to really close intimacy with Willard, like he’s taking us into confidence.

What I find incredibly attractive about this painting is not just the man himself, but how the painter has portrayed his personality. The strength of this portrait is the gaze, the expression; Willard is a performer. He's looking straight at us; also his posture, his erect pose is commanding. It takes over. I also love the shadow and highlight detail used in the flesh tones of his face, which show depth, which show texture, which show an expression. It's sculptural for me; he stands out as a sculpture. It's a 3D feeling when I see Willard; I feel he's in front of me, singing.

When I look at this portrait of the great opera singer Sir Willard White, painted by Ishbel Myerscough, I feel very, deeply unsure of myself. I will never have the charisma and confidence that this portrait exudes. No one will. Not even the real Willard White. Well, maybe him, but no one else. I mean, stand back and just look at him. He’s not just posing for a painting, he’s performing. We’re basically at one of his gigs. His chest is that puffed out because there’s a huge opera in it just bursting to get out. And, my god, that man can carry off a V-neck.

I like the way his eyes, and the general sense he’s better than me, follows me around the room. This painting really speaks to me for that reason. And what it’s saying is basically bullying, in the form of being obviously superior in every way. Maybe I just don’t want to be handsome and confident, Willard.

17.Title: Nile Rodgers
17.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

17.Title: intro
17.Info: So, this is Christabel Blackburn’s portrait of the multi-Grammy award-winning composer, producer and musical icon Nile Rodgers, and it’s oil paint on linen. It was Cristabel’s prize commission for winning Sky’s Portrait Artist of the Year in 2020, and it now hangs in the Royal Albert Hall.

Nile and Christabel really hit it off. I think partly because they're both naturally happier behind the scenes. In order to do what they have to do, they have to step up, outside their comfort zone and be on display, to be "on". But I think they're both actually quite shy. And so that was really a connection that they found with each other.

Nile wasn't entirely sure what to wear, and he took Christabel to his dressing room and said, "What do you think of these trousers? Are they too much? Should I wear them?". She loved them, they're both into fabrics. So she helped curate not just the portrait but what he was wearing and how he looked that day. Nile loved this portrait; he thought it really captured him. There's a sort of artificiality to it: there's an element of constructed reality. It's hanging in the Royal Albert Hall - Nile wanted it, he wanted to buy it or take it home! But unfortunately, he couldn't, because it belongs to the Royal Albert Hall - which is where it still hangs.

18.Title: Imelda Staunton
18.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

18.Title: is intro
18.Info: This is Liam Dickinson’s portrait of the beloved stage and screen actor Imelda Staunton, and it’s oil on canvas. This painting got Liam through to the final of Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the Year 2017.

18.Title: is 1
18.Info: Imelda Staunton, one of our finest actors. I know, as an actor myself, how difficult it can be to have our picture taken or a portrait made, because we're used to doing soimething; to being something. You're used to being active. But you can see here, Imelda is incredibly active: there's something going on there. She is an actor full of energy, full of life, and you can see how much there is going on there behind the eyes.

18.Title: is 2
18.Info: I think Liam's got a tremendous facility at capturing a likeness; almost a photographic ability. But it's not just a good likeness; it also does all the things that a good portrait should do; it puts his own spin on her, and it captures something of the day. Imelda came into this sitting in a Vivienne Westwood dress, and wellies, because I think she wanted to give the artists both sides of who she is; there's the red-carpet Imelda, and then there's the Imelda who loves gardening. her and her husband Jim Carter are huge gardening fanatics. So Liam put her in front of a rather lovely bush and flowers.

19.Title: Elaine Paige
19.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

19.Title: ep intro
19.Info: This is Toby Michael’s portrait of the First Lady of musical theatre, Elaine Paige. It’s oil on canvas, and it got Toby through to the final of Sky Arts Portrait Artist of the Year 2020.

19.Title: ep1
19.Info: Elaine is obviously a huge musical theatre star, and is used to standing on a stage, and captivating two thousand people, and I think the thing I remember most about that day is her incredible charisma. When she walked into the Battersea Arts Centre Grand Hall, she actually drew gasps from people. She had this magnificent red dress on, she sat down, kicked off her shoes. She's not a tall woman, she's very short, and was in front of a huge empty space with these lights hanging. But she filled it! I think artists need to be invited in, and Elaine was fantastic at just chatting to everybody. And I think what's so great about Toby's portrait is he captured her charisma, he captured her presence.

19.Title: ep2
19.Info: At the end of the show, we reveal all eight portraits, and it was one of the surrealist moments of my life, standing next to Elaine Paige, and looking at a further eight Elaine Paiges. It's always interesting who a sitter chooses, and what they see, compared to what we see. We all know what pictures of ourselves we like; other people will say, oh, you look fantastic in that, but sometimes we don't see that ourselves. And this was not the painting that Elaine chose , even though it was the one which got Toby through to the finals.

19.Title: ep3
19.Info: Toby's an interesting painter; he really takes what he does seriously. You can tell, he's very ambitious for himself and works incredibly hard. That makes him sound like he might be humourless about what he does, but he's not at all! He's a very relaxed guy, I enjoy talking to him a lot. But, he thinks a lot about what he's doing. And you can see here, there's some quite interesting rough brushstrokes behind, that give a vibrancy, I think, to the painting. The set feels alive behind her; there feels like there's a huge amount of energy there, which is appropriate because Elaine is someone who exudes a huge amount of energy!

20.Title: intro
20.Info: This is the Sunflowers by Vincent Van Gogh, painted in 1888. It’s in oil on canvas.

Why do people come back to this painting again and again? I think one reason is the story behind it. Van Gogh painted this for a specific room, for a specific occasion, to welcome his friend who was coming to visit. Van Gogh was desperate for friendship and for the respect of other painters, and he hoped that the famous painter Gauguin would want to join in his wild plans to form a community of artists. So he painted a whole series of sunflower images, including this one, to hang in the guest room before Gauguin arrived for a visit; yellow being a traditional colour of friendship. It’s such a simple gesture of welcome, such a clear desire for connection, and unfortunately the whole thing ends in disaster. We’ll never know the whole story, but Gauguin and Van Gogh had a huge argument, and at some point in the incident Van Gogh famously cut off part of his ear. Gauguin left, and the two never met again. It’s a story with a sad ending, like Van Gogh’s life, but also with an uplifting kind of afterlife: because now, this simple, hopeful painting has outlasted any disagreement and become one of the most famous and beloved pieces of art ever made.

What is it that’s so special about this painting? One answer is the way that Van Gogh used colour. He was experimenting with cutting-edge paint technology at this point: specifically, the tube of paint. Before this, paints had to be mixed by hand and used before they dried out, but the invention of the air-tight metal paint tube - the precursor to the modern plastic toothpaste tube - meant that artists could buy and store large amounts of vibrant new colours - including Chrome Yellow. And look what he did with all that new colour! There’s something luminous about this painting; it looks like it’s been lit from behind. When you see reproductions, or see it on posters you can see that, yes, it could be quite a conventional still life. But when the light hits it, this painting speaks to you, and it stands out like a lit window whether it’s on a street corner or in a room full of other masterpieces.

This painting is so much more than just a still life. The yellow colour is the first thing that grabs you, and Van Gogh loved to use that colour, but when you look at it there’s not just yellow - there’s burnt orange, and even golden parts within the flowers themselves, and the dark and light greenery of the stems and leaves gives it a real vibrancy. And then there’s a sudden darkness in the seed heads. And there’s more going on here than just a vase of flowers from the garden: many of these flowers are already dead, with their petals fallen and just the round seed head remaining - the flower on the far right has just one petal about to fall. So actually, this is a painting with a lot of dead things in it, but which also contains the seeds of new life.

20.Title: intro
20.Info: This is probably the best known of a series of sunflower paintings by Van Gogh, and it’s one of the world’s most famous pieces of art, and it hangs in the National Gallery

Ahhh, Van Gogh's Sunflowers. I know what you're thinking. That's not Van Gogh's. That's my nan's. She had that hanging in her kitchen for years before her cat died and she replaced it with that photo of Mr Mittens. Well, I'm sorry to hear about your nan's cat, but this is one of the most recognisable works of art in history. Mainly because it was painted by a genius as a present for Gaugin, another genius (a bit like Drake writing a particularly good rap for, I dunno, Snoop Dogg), but also because it is a lasting image that has been reproduced globally in magazines, art prints, posters, calendars, you name it. And who wouldn't want something this warm and melancholy hanging in their house? Doesn't beat seeing the real thing though, or even the amazing AR version right in front of you. Also, have a look. What were the chances of Van Gogh finding a vase with his name on it?

If you know anything about sunflowers, you’ll have already spotted that most of these are already dead. Look, that flower on the far right has got only one petal left!  I mean, they might all have freshly cut when Van Gogh started, but painting it clearly took a while. Van Gogh loved sunflowers so much that he painted them several times. Loads of times, really. It must have got to the point where he’d say “Hey, everyone! Guess what? I’ve done a new painting” and people would just go “I swear, Vince, if this is more flipping sunflowers, you’re going to get a clip round the… oh, never mind.”

21.Title: Jazzie B
21.Tomb2: Sky Portrait Artist of the Year

21.Title: intro
21.Info: This is Tom Mead's 2019 portrait of hugely successful music producer and Soul II Soul pioneer Jazzie B, or Jazzie B OBE to give him his full title.

There's a great sense of movement to it. I suppose this is the man who wrote 'Keep on Moving, Don't Stop', so it's appropriate. We seem to be implying that he's doing two things at once, there's more than one direction. There's a lot going on, he's a busy man. He's not only a busy man; he's also a very successful man: just look at all those gold discs in the background. Tom can really draw a wonderful head, and we get two for the price of one here! We get a very thoughtful, interesting, great likeness, but also a very unique take on a man who's obviously quite restless, quite busy, quite productive... it's a wonderful piece of art.

Tom's a really accomplished painter, and can create a great likeness. This is a beautiful three-dimensional rendition of a person on a flat surface, so technically he's really brilliant. But I think what I love about him is his sense of style. The colours he uses, the colour palette; it's a really beautiful, gorgeous piece of painting, that I think has captured the seriousness, the intelligence, and the creativity of Jazzie B.

It's really interesting having musicians sit for portraits, because obviously their medium is sound, and we're looking at something visual. Jazzie B was very smart, very comfortable in his own skin, which I think Tom really gets here. There's a lot going on behind those eyes, there's a man who thinks deep thoughts and then translates them into great music. Tom has looked at this guy, and translated it into a very fine piece of art.

22.Title: intro
22.Info: This is a portrait of the musician, actor and pop icon David Bowie by Stephen Finer in 1994, and it’s in oil on canvas.

This painting of David Bowie by Stephen Finer is something of a magic eye picture. If you look at it long enough, you’ll see David Bowie change style constantly, just like the great man himself. If you thought it didn’t look much like him at first glance, I’m sure by now you’ll agree that this painting is probably David Bowie’s passport photo. Look at it and you can see the pale ghostliness of The Thin White Duke... but blink! There he is as the alien from The Man Who Fell To Earth. Blink! He’s Ziggy Stardust. Blink! He’s a greengrocer from Wolverhampton. Well, he would have got to that eventually.

There’s so much movement in this portrait, and that says just as much about how the artist works as it does about David Bowie. Painter Stephen Finer likes to spend long hours in his studio getting to know his model and the paint somehow just slowly appears on the canvas, bit by bit, until he’s captured whoever is sitting for him. And that’s why it’s all a bit blurry. No one can expect David Bowie to sit still for long. Bowie recorded three albums during this and changed his hairstyle four times. Luckily, the perm didn’t make it into the final painting.

The artist Stephen Finer and David Bowie both grew up at the same time in Bromley, and during the 60s, they both hung out at art collectives in the area. Because they were both so cool, they never actually spoke to one another until the 1990s, when Stephen finally caught the eye of Bowie after the singer saw his painting of Marlene Deitrich. From that meeting, Stephen painted Bowie several times including one portrait with David’s wife Iman. Probably got some sort of two-for-one deal by then, I imagine. All the best artists do loyalty cards.

Even though this is such an abstract painting, one of the most abstract images in the whole National Portrait Gallery, it’s still unmistakably David Bowie. So much of it is the pose and the profile, the position of the head on the shoulders; it has animation, and feels like it’s always in motion. And there’s a suggestion of an eye there, looking out from between the brushstrokes. Or, what I imagine to be an eye - there can be many different eyes - but that’s because I think this painting is about imagination. Just like Bowie’s work. So for me, I almost imagine that eye almost peeking out through this curtain of colour, like he’s backstage, getting ready for his performance.

Stephen Finer, the artist who made this painting, uses paint as a moving, changing thing, which feels very fitting for the chameleon of pop. Finer would deliberately let his paint slide and drip and form new shapes, and so it’s almost as if the painting captures a single movement in a process of change and evolution. The more I look at it, the more it reminds me not so much of Boiew, but of his quality, his manner and his performance. Because he was a masquerader; always incarnating himself into different identities. And so this painting isn’t just another snapshot of David during one of his phases, but captures something of that essence of constant change.

23.Title: intro
23.Info: This is the Wilton Diptych. It’s in tempera, which means ground-up paint mixed with egg yolk, and it’s on two oak panels with a hinge. We’re looking at the two inner panels with the hinge down the middle. We don’t know who painted it, but it was probably around 1395.

What is a diptych? Well, you’ve asked the right person. There’s very little I don’t know about diptychs. Mainly because there’s very little to know about diptychs. A diptych is a painting on two separate wooden panels that are hinged together and can be closed just like a book. This one is from the 1300s. Of course, you don’t see many of them these days, because people prefer to look at their diptychs on Kindle or listen to them on an audio painting.

You’re looking at a very gold and very medieval artwork painted for King Richard II using tempera, which is, as we all know (and I’m not just reading this), a mixture of powdered paint and egg yolk.) So, if you bought this priceless piece and decided it didn’t fit in your lounge, you could always fry it up. No one knows who painted this incredibly important work back around 1395-1399, so, I’m going to say it was me. No one can prove it wasn’t. It’s a painting in two halves. Look to the left, you’ll see Richard II himself, kneeling with some of his saintly friends, while on the right we have heavenly angels and, of course, Mary the blessed virgin. No idea who the baby is.

When you look at the picture on the wall like this, remember that it’s not just another canvas. It’s solid wood and hinged so that it can be shut like a book, possibly so that it could be safely carried around with the King’s retinue through the dangerous and unpredictable world of 14th-century England. It’s portable, and I think it’s very personal, because it was probably only used by Richard himself, for personal prayer and devotion, and as a reminder of the link between his power and the Church. It’s almost like a private little chapel which could be carried wherever the King went. I think that’s something very special; you’re looking at something that wasn’t made for public consumption; a breathtakingly beautiful artwork that was private to the most powerful man in the country over six hundred years ago; and now it’s here for all to see.

This picture is as personal as a fingerprint, and as private as a diary. It’s full of details which mark it as a specific, custom piece of art intended for one man, King Richard II of England. On the left panel, the three men standing are all saints important to Richard; Richard himself is kneeling on the ground, wearing a gold collar with broom-pods, the symbol of his dynasty. Even the blue-clad angels on the right-hand panel all have a badge in the shape of a white hart or stag, another of Richard’s symbols; it’s almost as if he’s branded them with his logo. But, in the politics of Richard’s time, these badges were very controversial; he’s really saying, all these angels are part of my household; that even angels owe fealty to the King.

24.Title: intro
24.Info:
This is Albrecht Dürer’s painting of Saint Jerome. It’s a small, two-sided painting in oil on pearwood, though you can only see the front side here. It was probably made for private worship, and finished about 1496. 
This Winter at the National Gallery you can see Dürer, Germany’s greatest Renaissance artist, come to life. Come and witness Dürer’s breath-taking artistry and join him on his journey round Europe with the Credit Suisse Exhibition ‘Dürer’s Journeys: Travels of a Renaissance Man’.

You know how sometimes people end up looking just like their pets? Well this lion bears an uncanny resemblance to Saint Jerome himself! The lion is an important part of the story of Saint Jerome - he is said to have removed a thorn from a lion’s paw, taming it, during his wanderings in the wilderness. According to the tale, after converting to Christianity Jerome became disillusioned with the worldly temptations of Rome, and escaped to live as a hermit in the desert outside Bethlehem. You can see here how Dürer has used fine brushstrokes to highlight the mane of the lion, just like he’s used for the Saint’s beard - they seem to embody gentleness and power at the same time.

Saint Jerome is often associated with revelation and the Biblical end of the world, and there’s something very dramatic, even a bit apocalyptic about the sky in this painting too - do you think it’s a sunrise or a sunset? Either way, it’s as if the Saint’s time in the wilderness has lasted right up until the end of the world, and the way the clouds parted above his head looks almost like a halo. You can’t see the back of this painting (unless you come into the Gallery, that is!), but it shows a dark, cloudy sky with a fiery red comet or meteor, which might also suggest the end of the world too.

There are several key symbols at the bottom of this painting - most prominently the book the saint holds in his hands, a reminder of Jerome’s most famous achievement - translating the Bible from Hebrew and Greek into Latin. Nearby on the ground is a robe and hat of the same red colour - to an audience in Dürer’s time, the late Fifteenth Century, this was the unmistakable uniform of a Cardinal of the church. Although this uniform didn’t exist in the Fourth Century when Jerome lived, the symbolism is clear - he has set aside his office and rank in order to be closer to God. And don’t miss the tiny birds in the bottom right corner - these are goldfinches, often used as symbols of the Passion of Christ. One popular medieval legend said that the red colour on their breast was caused when a goldfinch flew down and plucked a thorn from Jesus’s head, and was splashed with his blood.

This is a portrait of Saint Jerome, painted in 1496 by Germany’s greatest Renaissance artist Albrecht Dürer. Saint Jerome lived in the desert just outside Bethlehem, leading the life of a hermit. Which is probably just as well. As you can see from the painting, Jerome was so committed to his faith that he would beat himself with a rock in empathy with Christ’s pain. Bit much. No wonder no one came to visit. You know you’ve gone too far when even a lion gives you a dirty look. You just know exactly what that lion is thinking. 'I was going to eat him, but I’ve gone right off him. He’s too weird.'

Dürer’s portrait of Saint Jerome is pretty small. It’s only 23 centimetres by 17 centimetres. So, it's about the size of a 7 inch single. It even has a b-side. There’s a painting of a comet on the reverse side. The reason the portrait is that size is so it was easy to carry around. There was no Instagram back in 1496, so if you wanted to scroll through your pics on the bus, you had to bring the actual paintings with you. Which was great if you liked Saint Jerome, but a real pain if you were into, for instance, the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. So, who carried this artwork around? We don’t know for sure, but the painting was probably made for private worship. Which is also exactly how Instagram works.

Saint Jerome was thought to have seen an injured lion, saw that the problem was that the lion had a thorn in his paw, and so he went over to the lion and removed the thorn, thus becoming friends with the lion. And that’s what we learn from this great work. If you get the chance to do a lion a favour, jump at it. You have got a mate for life. You’ll never not get that table at the pub. The painting is full of religious symbolism, which is fair. He’s a saint. That’s his thing. The bright yellow of the sunrise in the background represents the intensity of Jerome’s prayer, but also he’s beating himself with a rock, and the dark, foreboding sky suggests something potentially terrible is on its way. The end of the world or judgement day perhaps? Good luck, God. No way am I judging a man who is mates with a lion.

25.Title: intro
25.Info: This painting by Van Gogh is called Van Gogh’s chair. It’s oil on canvas, painted around 1888. You can see this painting along with more than 2000 others, part of one of the world’s greatest art collections, at the National Gallery, so book a free visit today!

This painting, ‘Van Gogh’s Chair’, is one of a pair of chair paintings by Van Gogh, with the other being ‘Gauguin’s Chair’. Gauguin was a successful artist, much more so than Van Gogh, and Van Gogh had invited him to Arles in the South of France, desperately hoping that the more famous painter would join in with Van Gogh’s plan to form an artist’s commune. Van Gogh may even have bought the two chairs specifically for Gauguin’s visit. Van Gogh began work on the two chair paintings in the early part of Gauguin’s visit, when things seemed to be going well. They are quite companionable companion pieces, but they also reflect the two artists’ very different personalities. Where Gauguin’s chair is an elaborate, imposing piece in darker colours, here we can see Van Gogh’s chair is simple and rustic, but set in bright sunlight and with quite cheerful colours. Sadly Gauguin’s visit ended in tragedy - after some kind of argument between the two, Van Gogh famously mutilated his ear, Gauguin left, and the two never spoke again. After a stay in hospital, we know that Van Gogh continued working on this painting. From his simple pipe and tobacco, resting on the seat, to the knots and imperfections in the wooden legs, it’s clear there is something intensely personal about this image.You can find out more about Gauguin’s disastrous visit to Van Gogh, and how it influenced Van Gogh’s paintings by finding Van Gogh’s Sunflowers in the Augmented Gallery, at Fortnum and Mason’s on Piccadilly.

This painting of a simple, empty chair on a bare tiled floor is one of Van Gogh’s most iconic works. There’s often a sense of absence when an artist shows us an empty chair, and Van Gogh wrote that he had wept when he saw his father’s vacant chair after his father’s death in 1885. He also owned and loved an engraving by Luke Fildes called ‘The Empty Chair’, which showed the deserted study and chair of the novelist Charles Dickens on the day he died. And yet, this is a bright, sturdy image of a chair which Van Gogh has infused with his personality. Look at the blue edging on the yellow chair legs, how boldly they stand out. And look at the chair leg nearest to us - it’s at an angle, and might seem to be a bit wonky or unsteady, but I think this gives the chair a strong stance, a sense of squaring up to us as we look at it. Finally, don’t miss the simple box on the left edge of the painting, which bears Van Gogh’s signature, ‘Vincent’, and which seems to hold sprouting onions - a sign of new life, and maybe a sign of hope.

You’re looking at Van Gogh’s Chair. An aptly titled painting, as that is definitely Van Gogh’s chair taking up practically all of the canvas. It was painted in 1888 and one of a pair of furniture based artworks Vincent Van Gogh did that year along with Gaugin’s Chair, which was a painting of five dogs playing poker. No, only joking, it was actually a painting of Gaugin’s chair. There’s quite a big difference in the two paintings. Gaugin’s chair is elegant and finely carved with novels sitting on the seat, it’s in darkness too which gives it an air of mystery. While Van Gogh’s chair, as we can see here, is simple and functional with his pipe and tobacco sitting on it. It’s a much more humble painting. Keep in mind that, in 1990, one of Van Gogh’s paintings sold for $75 million. So, remember: stay modest, kids. There’s money in it.
