Van Gogh’s chair. Well, it’s just a chair, isn’t it? But it’s not just what’s in the painting that’s interesting, it’s what’s absent. Where’s Vincent? Yes, yes, yes. He’s painting the chair, isn’t he? That’s not the point. The point is Vincent Van Gogh’s fascination with absence. It began a few years before this painting after Vincent’s father died and the sight of his father’s empty chair brought the artist to tears. The empty chair, isolated within the canvas, has poignancy. It asks you to look and consider what is absent. A chair left vacant can become a memento of the person who once rested there. Not my chair, though. There’s normally just crumbs and a big bum imprint.

Van Gogh’s Chair and its twin painting Gauguin’s Chair were meant to be hung together, with one chair turned to the right and the other to the left, like they were sitting together. They were both painted at Vincent’s home in Arles, Southern France, when the artist Paul Gauguin visited there from his home in Paris. Sadly, and famously, that symbol of friendship went right out the window (as so many friendships do) the night that Van Gogh threatened Gaugin with a knife and then he cut a part of his own left ear off. Gauguin suddenly remembered he’d left the oven on and returned to Paris pretty sharpish. And sadly, Vincent never saw his friend again.

26.Title: intro
26.Info: This is Saint Catherine of Alexandria by the Renaissance master Raphael. It’s oil on poplar , and was painted about 1507. You can see a very different portrayal of Saint Catherine by Artemisia Gentileschi as part of the Augmented Gallery, on the other side of the National Gallery.Raphael’s life was short, his work prolific, and his legacy immortal. He captured in his art the human and the divine; love and friendship; learning and power. Find out more about this legendary artist in the Credit Suisse Exhibition: Raphael, opening at the National Gallery in Spring 2022.

I think this is just such a beautiful painting. Many of Raphael’s works are very angelic, and have such an extraordinary quality to them. Saint Catherine was converted to Christianity after seeing a vision of Christ, and here we can see her looking up towards a heavenly glow in the sky with a kind of mild ecstasy. Even though we know that Catherine was a martyr who was tortured for her beliefs, in this painting there’s primarily a sense of joy, as though we’re seeing the moment of revelation. She’s turning her face upward and away from us, as if she has a private understanding with heaven, where she knows she’ll soon be going. The faintest trace of a halo around her head reminds us of her connection with the golden light in the sky.

The colours and textures of the fabric in this painting are fabulous. They dominate the painting with strong colour, almost like a flag. The blue of Saint Catherine’s robe may be meant to evoke the Virgin Mary, while the red of her outer robe, and the way it almost pours over the wheel in the bottom right, may be meant to remind us of blood and the Saint’s martyrdom - in the legend Saint Catherine was threatened with torture upon the wheel, before God destroyed it with a thunderbolt. And don’t miss the gauzy, almost completely transparent cloth going across her breast and over her shoulder - Raphael really is a master of these delicate textures.

Many Renaissance paintings of saints have landscapes in the background; here Raphael has painted an unusually beautiful and well-defined Italian-looking landscape, with distant hills and a river running across the middle of the painting with a crystal-clear reflection of the landscape above. It’s almost as if this reflects the clarity of the moment of revelation. The horizon of the painting is quite low, below the level of Catherine’s shoulders, which gives her a huge amount of sky to stare into. And Catherine herself looms very large in this painting - she occupies a lot of space and seems to be a scale larger than the landscape, as though she is a giantess whose spiritual stature makes her too big for this world.

This portrait of Saint Catherine of Alexandria was painted by Raphael in 1507 and it has an absolutely incredible back story. Catherine was a princess in the 4th century, she converted to Christianity and, during a vision, married Jesus. Good catch, Catherine. His dad has houses EVERYWHERE. Then Emperor Maxentius, who immediately sounds like a bad egg, gets so cross - because Catherine refuses to give up her faith and her new husband - that he orders Catherine to be tied to a spiked wheel and tortured to death. Oh, no! How is Catherine going to get out of this one? Easy. The spiked wheel gets hit by a lightning bolt and is destroyed. Hooray! Well done, Catherine. That showed them! Anyway, they cut her head off after that, but she was doing great up until then.

Catherine is depicted here in very calm and peaceful surroundings, relaxing maybe a bit too much on the spiked wheel which has been chosen for her death. Raphael has chosen to highlight her faith. The dandelions in the foreground are a symbol of Christian grief, Catherine’s hand on her heart shows her devotion and she gazes upwards to a golden break in the clouds looking at Heaven itself as if to say 'yeah, any time now with that lightning bolt would be great, thanks.'

Raphael was a master of the High Renaissance period, and, like Bradley Walsh, he could do everything. Painter, draughtsman, architect, archaeologist, poet. He did the lot. He was also incredible at beatboxing, and he always won at pub quizzes, although I’ve just been told that I made those last two things up and I’m not to do it again. Fine. Doing all those amazing things and he still had time to squeeze this in and so many classic artworks. He was so prolific, it’s no wonder he’s thought of as part of the great trinity of renaissance masters along with Da Vinci and Michaelangelo, and it probably explains why he died of exhaustion at 37. Say what you like about Timmy Mallet or Banksy but they know when to put their feet up.

27.Title: Hélène Rouart in her Father's Study
intro
27.Info: This is Hélène Rouart in her Father’s Study by the French painter Degas. It’s oil on canvas, and it was painted around 1886.This painting is about to go on the road! It’s touring to three venues around the UK as part of the National Gallery’s commitment to sharing art across the nation. So if you’re near Gallery Oldham in Greater Manchester, Glan-yr-afon in Pembrokeshire or Kirkby Gallery in Merseyside, pop in and pay Hélène a visit!

This painting is called Hélène Rouart in her Father’s Study, but in many ways it’s not about Hélène at all, but about her father, who was an old friend of Degas, a fellow painter and an art collector. Hélène stands amongst her father’s art collection, behind her father’s empty chair. And she seems almost dwarfed by the size of that chair, doesn’t she? She’s kind of fenced off by it - she’s edged back almost flat against the wall, and there seems to be very little space in this room, or in this painting, for her. Look at the empty chair of the father, here, and compare it to Van Gogh’s own painting of an empty chair, which you can find in the Augmented Gallery on Trafalgar Square. Though they both prominently show empty chairs, the two paintings create very different moods and different kinds of absence.

Degas was an old friend of the Rouart family, and had actually painted Hélène before when she was much younger - just nine years old - sitting on her father’s knee. Before making this painting, Degas had planned to paint a double portrait of Hélène with her mother, perhaps as a companion piece to the one with her father, but unfortunately by this time Hélène’s mother had died. Instead, we have Hélène, now aged twenty-three, surrounded by her father’s collection of antiquities and objets d’art - that is, pieces of art - but she’s also hedged around with absences and signs of death, from the area of plain wall behind her shoulder, which creates a triangle of negative space in the centre of the canvas, to the blank documents on her father’s desk. Even the Egyptian funeral statues in the glass case to the left - they have their backs to Hélène, and we know that Degas exaggerated their size. They’re much bigger here than the real ones which Rouart owned, so Hélène is shrunk even further by comparison. It’s almost as though Degas is making her just another object in her father’s collection.

You’re looking at Hélène Rouart in Her Father’s Study, painted around 1886 by Degas. As far as titles of paintings go, this one is phenomenally accurate. That is definitely - and I won’t hear any arguments about this - Hélène Rouart in her father’s study. I mean, if Degas decided to call it ‘Hélène Rouart in a Batman Outfit’ or ‘Hélène Rouart in the Middle of a Snooker Match’, we’d all be furious. But, luckily, Degas painted exactly what was asked of him. He was commissioned to paint Hélène by her father, in the same way that famous people these days are commissioned to do videos on Cameo. It’s not exactly like that. No one talks about ‘Happy Birthday, Maureen by Van Gogh’ or Monet’s late-period masterpiece ‘Get Well Soon, Rodney’.

This isn’t the first time Degas painted Hélène. Before this, he painted her sitting on her dad’s knee. Not immediately before this, obviously, it was 14 years earlier. She was only 9. Might be a bit of a strain to sit for hours for a portrait with a fully grown adult sitting on you. Although, looking at the size of that chair, I reckon Hélène’s dad might actually be a giant. Hélène looks dwarfed by the chair and all the other objects in her father's collection. Degas even painted those Egyptian statues much bigger than they were in real life. So, we can only imagine how tiny Hélène must have been in real life.

I’m starting to think that yet another birthday will go by without anyone commissioning a portrait of me by Degas. Clearly, unlike Hélène here, my dad doesn’t want me to have a portrait of me in his study. And, I suppose, Degas has been dead for ages now. It’s never going to happen. But that is exactly what Henri Rouart, Hélène’s father and Edgar Degas’s friend, wanted. He didn’t want a painting of his daughter in her own environment surrounded by her own things. No, he wanted a beautiful painting of his study and all the possessions he’s collected. Paintings, drawings, Egyptian statues, Chinese artworks, a stupidly big chair, his own daughter and we can only conclude that Hélène’s father was really very hard work.
